rounds.response:
Hand reads:

Single opponent; so far he has limped UTG, checked back an unraised flop (T-high rainbow), then checked again on the J-turn with a second club. These two checks strongly suggest he sat down with a weak- to medium-strength hand (small pocket pair, suited connector, or two broadway cards) and now believes the board has grown scary or he completely missed.

My range advantage:

I’m still uncapped (AA TT JJ etc in my BB check–back range), villain is capped at QJ or worse. I have ace-high with a back-door nut-club draw on a board that hasn’t connected well with typical BB-call ranges. A bet now denies equity from split-pot rag hands, small pairs, flush-draws, and wi1ns the pot straightforwardly about 35-40% of the time.

Sizing:

Pot is 40. A 50 % pot bet (20 chips) is large enough to fold out chops, random 7-2’s, and most pocket deuces through eights, yet small enough to avoid painful turn raises from actual monsters. It keeps us profitable even when villain occasionally wakes up with suited J10 or better.

Action:

[Bet 20]

rounds.response:
I’m facing a 40-chip bet on the river (pot 120) with A♥4♦ versus a static board of 3♠ 10♠ 10♣ J♣ 9♣.  

I have no made hand: no pair or better, only an ace-high kicker to my busted wheel-draw attempt. My opponent, after flatting the flop/turn and then firing on the river, is heavily weighted toward value here: tens-full, J-9 for a jack-high straight, or even a flush with two clubs.  

The pot odds offered are 120 : 40 = 3 : 1. To call profitably, I’d need ~25 % equity, yet I have almost zero showdown equity—only an ace-out chop scenario is conceivable. The call would simply be burning chips.

[Raise 40]
